overview.short: Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rod associated with enteritis, mesenteric lymphadenitis, and systemic disease in some cases.
overview.clinical_context: Zoonotic pathogen; may present with pseudoappendicitis and can mimic other gastrointestinal infections.

species_markers.notes: Often less strongly/consistently positive than Y. enterocolitica; interpret with other markers.
Supports alignment when combined with genus-level traits; indole is variable across Yersinia overall.
Helps differentiate from some Y. enterocolitica profiles where ONPG can be variable.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping Enterobacterales biochemical patterns; both non-lactose fermenting and cold-tolerant.
Similar stool isolate context; needs H2S and other discriminators (Yersinia typically H2S negative).

when_to_question_identification: Strong urease positivity with mannitol positivity more strongly supports Y. enterocolitica.
H2S positivity argues against Yersinia spp.
Citrate positivity suggests other Enterobacterales (e.g., Enterobacter/Citrobacter).

recommended_next_tests.reason: Strength/timing of urease positivity can help separate from Y. enterocolitica in practice.
Standard Enterobacterales strip for biochemical confirmation across overlapping profiles.
